importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The year when the LEAP trial results were published, leading to new medical guidelines recommending early introduction of peanuts to infants, marking a pivotal shift in allergy prevention practices.
When expanded guidelines for early allergen introduction were issued, leading to a significant decline in peanut allergy rates among U.S. children.

The updated medical guidance recommending the introduction of peanuts and other allergens between four and six months of age, without prior screening, now forms the foundation of current best practices.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The decade following the 2015 LEAP trial saw a measurable public health impact, with declining rates of peanut allergies in the U.S., demonstrating the real-world effectiveness of early allergen introduction.

keyTakeAways: The rate of peanut allergies in children ages 0 to 3 decreased by over 27% after 2015 and by over 40% after 2017 due to early introduction guidelines.
Approximately 60,000 children (corrected to 40,000) have avoided peanut allergies since 2015, with 40,000 avoiding peanut allergies specifically.
Early allergen introduction, especially of peanuts, has been shown to reduce future allergy risk by over 80% in the LEAP trial.
The updated 2021 guidelines recommend introducing peanuts and other major food allergens between four and six months of age, without screening or testing.
Despite the strong scientific foundation, adoption of the guidelines has been slow, with only about 29% of pediatricians and 65% of allergists reporting adherence in 2017.

Medical experts and parents initially questioned whether early introduction could be safely implemented outside clinical settings, but new research shows it is being adopted and making measurable public health impacts.
Advocacy groups such as Food Allergy Research & Education (FARE) support early allergen introduction as a meaningful strategy to reduce the incidence and prevalence of peanut allergies nationwide.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A decade after a landmark study showed that early introduction of peanuts to infants reduces the risk of developing peanut allergies, new research confirms that real-world implementation of this guidance has led to a significant decline in allergy rates. Since 2015, the rate of peanut allergies in young children has dropped by over 27% and by over 40% after expanded guidelines in 2017. The research, led by Dr. David Hill at Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia and published in Pediatrics, analyzed electronic health records from numerous pediatric practices and found that about 40,000 children have avoided peanut allergies since 2015. The findings are rooted in the LEAP trial led by Gideon Lack at King’s College London, which demonstrated that early exposure reduces allergy risk by more than 80%. Despite initial hesitance and slow adoption—only 29% of pediatricians and 65% of allergists followed the guidelines—evidence now shows that early allergen introduction is being adopted and is having a measurable public health impact. Advocacy groups like FARE support these practices, recommending parents introduce peanut butter, milk-based yogurt, soy-based yogurt, and tree nut butters between four and six months of age, without screening. This shift represents a major advancement in preventive medicine for food allergies.
title: Early Peanut Introduction in Infants Reduces Allergy Rates, Study Finds
